translation2: All Bosch power tools, pneumatic tools, and measuring tools are carefully inspected, tested, and subjected to strict controls by the Bosch quality assurance. Therefore, Bosch offers a guarantee for Bosch power tools, pneumatic tools, and measuring tools. The warranty claims of the buyer from the purchase contract with the seller, as well as legal rights, are not restricted by this guarantee. For these tools, we provide warranty according to the following conditions: We provide warranty by correcting the defects in the tool that are demonstrably based on a material or manufacturing defect within the warranty period on the tool, free of charge. The warranty period is 24 months, for commercial or professional use or equivalent use 12 months. The warranty period begins with the purchase by the first end user. The decisive date is the date on the original purchase receipt. For all power tools and measuring tools purchased from 01.09.2004 for professional use (with the exception of high-frequency tools, industrial battery-operated screwdrivers, and pneumatic tools) the warranty period is extended to 36 months, if the buyer registers these tools within 4 weeks after the purchase date. Battery packs and chargers as well as accessories are excluded from this warranty extension. The registration can only be made online at [www.bosch-pt.com/warranty](http://www.bosch-pt.com/warranty). As confirmation, the registration receipt, which must be printed immediately, as well as the original purchase receipt, from which the purchase date can be derived, are valid. Registration is only possible if the buyer agrees to the storage of their personal data. The warranty is excluded for: Parts that are subject to normal wear and tear, as well as defects in the tool that are due to normal wear and tear, improper use, abnormal environmental conditions, unusual operating conditions, overloading, or insufficient maintenance or care. Defects in the tool caused by the use of non-Bosch spare parts or accessories. Tools on which modifications or additions have been made. Minor deviations from the specified condition that are insignificant for the value and usability of the tool. The elimination of the warranty-covered defect is carried out in the following way: We repair the defective tool at our discretion free of charge or replace it with a flawless tool (possibly also a successor model). Replaced tools or parts become our property.
gpt_response: { "Fluency": { "Score": "5", "Explanation": "The text is highly fluent, with no grammatical errors, unnatural wording, or stiff syntax. translation2: Is tire choice when cycling really as safe as advertised? This morning, I woke up full of determination because I wanted to at least train a little for my upcoming cycling tour next week. Well, I got started and I rode my new racing bike, which I bought on eBay yesterday. The first 40km were great - but then what happened, which always lurks in every city center (this time: Krefeld!) happened. Glass shards on the road. Zack, loud hissing and my rear tire didn't want to participate in the rest of the ride. Since I didn't have a real opportunity due to the weekday, I couldn't get a replacement tube and tube, so I had to turn around with a half-hearted mood and take the first train home. It wasn't as bad as technically, maybe it's better if I practice the tire change before the cycling tour. Now I stand before a question and hope that you can help me. Since I have a relatively long distance to cover over several days, I would very much like to avoid this problem again and again. Now it wasn't so bad, since the old tires from the previous owner (a very nice old man, who rode 140km on the day I picked up the bike until 2:12pm!) and he also described them as suboptimal, because he had been riding on them for several years. But when I think about having to change the tire after 80-90km of riding, I'm afraid I'm not in a good mood:D Now, I've had a conversation with an older man at the platform who asked me why I didn't have Marathon Plus tires; these are supposed to be unbreakable. It sounds very tempting. But are they really that indestructible? I don't want to spend 40€/tire now, just to be disappointed later. Furthermore, I wonder: I currently have 25x622 on my racing bike. That's apparently also available with Marathon Plus tires, but most of them are wider. Is this a problem? Or would you advise me to a different tire for a racing bike in general? The Schwalbe side seems to be my absolute! I have little knowledge in this area, so I'm more inclined to recommend the Durano DD. Thank you in advance for the help and warm greetings!

There are no grammar or spelling errors and it contains natural phrasing and vocabulary usage appropriate for a casual, informal context. The text flows smoothly from sentence to sentence and idea to idea, in a logical and coherent manner." } }

translation2: The party that we wanted to throw: Frankfurt celebrates after a thrilling comeback against Leverkusen. What a spectacular reaction from Eintracht Frankfurt. After 22 minutes, the last two-time champions in a row seemed to be on their way to the next Bundesliga relegation. But then the SGE turned around, shot off their frustration over a mediocre start to the season within an hour and won wildly with 5:2. "It's crazy what the guys have accomplished today," coach Oliver Glasner shouted at DAZN and gave a "blanket compliment to everyone who was there," adding that it initially looked like another dampener for the Frankfurt team, which was still in ninth place despite their expectations. Patrik Schick had put Leverkusen in the lead with 2:0. What happened next impressed even the SGE coach. "How the players then came back and showed a fantastic performance," Glasner continued. I'm crazy happy with the performance we showed and of course with the result. Even defensive player Christopher Lenz, who could finally play again after four games and his overcome muscle injury, emphasized the morale of his teammates. "I think our mentality is incredible," said the 27-year-old and was particularly pleased with the result for the fans. That was the party we wanted to throw. But for the upcoming tasks, Glasner wants to keep the focus on himself and sees himself well prepared in terms of personnel. It's extraordinary that we have all players fit in December and that all players are physically in top form. It's top work in our medical department, but also the players live highly professionally. Now we want to "step by step" and "stay humble" and run the tasks until the end of the year "at this level." As next, already on Wednesday in the course of the English week, an away game at Borussia Mönchengladbach (5:30 p.m., Sky) is on the program.

translation2: Problems with Glass Fiber + Devolo DLan/Magic  We have had a new glass fiber connection in the house for a few weeks now. Unfortunately, I am now having problems building a stable WiFi network. Before, I had a DSL 50 Mbit connection and used Devolo DLan, which worked flawlessly with a few exceptions and received and transmitted 50 Mbit. The new glass fiber connection sends 500 Mbit to the FritzBox 7590 and at the DLan module, which is connected to the FritzBox, these also come in. However, at the other DLan module, which sends the WiFi, not the full 500 Mbit, but the further I move away from the module with the device, the less comes in (i.e., use a power outlet that is 1, 2, 3, etc. rooms away from the other module). This leads to the fact that the Internet with the new glass fiber connection is now even slower on the first floor than before (~45 Mbit). I have also ordered a new Devolo Magic Set, which apparently uses a new technology. This was slightly better than DLan, but here too there were similar losses. Could someone explain to me why so much internet speed is lost over the power line with glass fiber? And is LAN really the only solution? It would be extremely time-consuming to lay LAN cables throughout the house. I am really at my wit's end, which is why I created this extra account. Therefore, I would be especially grateful for a response.

translation2: Since its introduction in 2001, the Valvetronix series from VOX has continuously evolved, leading to the combination of advanced modeling technology with the "Valve Reactor" circuit, which perfectly imitates the behavior of a tube amplifier. With the VT20X/VT40X/VT100X amplifiers, we are presenting a brand new modeling engine that is absolutely state-of-the-art in terms of sound. Thanks to the VET (Virtual Element Technology) technology, which is based on the analysis of components and amplifier circuits, the VTX amplifiers wait with an authenticity that is absolutely impressive. Of course, these amps also include the multi-stage Valvetronix tube preamplifier, which partly relies on genuine analog circuits because these better capture the variations and nuances of a tube amplifier than any simulation. In addition to this sophisticated circuitry, the VTX amplifiers offer a closed housing and a bass reflex system, from which the natural resonances just flow. With the "Tone Room" software from VOX, you can even correct and bend historical facts on the virtual level until the amp and effects sound exactly as you have always imagined them. The perfect combination of tube sound with modeling technology is primarily due to the 2001 introduced VOX Valve Reactor technology. Of course, it has been refined several times since then to meet new sound requirements, which led to a performance boost of the VOX Valvetronix series in 2010 - with more dynamics as well as numerous and significantly improved amplifier models. From the compact VT20+ to the VT120+ with two speakers, the new VT+ Valvetronix series has been designed in such a way that all guitarists searching for maximum sound diversity will find what they are looking for. All guitarists dream of the compression and dynamics of a tube amplifier: they expect a fat sound, a nuanced reproduction of playing dynamics and string attack, as well as a prompt response. During an in-depth analysis, the VOX engineers discovered that the output stage determines the tube character of an amplifier and developed the VOX Valve Reactor technology based on this finding. The Valve Reactor circuit of each VT+ amplifier, equipped with a 12AX7 tube, perfectly reproduces the behavior, subtle nuances, and sound character of a tube amplifier.
gpt_response: { "Fluency": { "Score": "5", "Explanation": "The text is highly fluent and well articulated. There are no grammatical errors, unnatural wording or stiff syntax. The text flows smoothly and is easy to understand." } }

translation2: Federal Minister Klara Geywitz: Expropriation does not create new housing The new Federal Minister Klara Geywitz (SPD) has spoken out against the expropriation of large housing corporations as demanded in a popular vote in Berlin. "With expropriation, not a single new apartment is created, it only changes the ownership structure," Geywitz said in an interview with the "Tagesspiegel" (Sunday). My goal is to give tenants security that their rent will remain affordable in the coming years. A mix of private landlords, cooperatives, or housing companies is the best protection against monopolization. In Berlin, the coalition of SPD, Greens, and Left Party plans to set up an expert commission, as recommended by the popular vote. However, if the situation does not calm down, Geywitz has just started talks with the FDP in the traffic light coalition about further tightening of the rental law. The coalition agreement provides for a rent brake until 2029, a limit on landlord increases in tight housing markets, and the expansion of the rent cap. I will speak with the Justice Minister to implement this as quickly as possible. If the rental market does not calm down, "we will discuss further steps with the coalition partners," emphasized the SPD politician.

translation2: I am bored with Sky Sport F1 Hello dear F1 fans, throughout the season, the quality on the German Sky has gradually decreased, so I want to vent a bit in this post. First of all, the transmission was interrupted during the F2 race to start the F1 coverage on time. Although the delayed start and the start accident put the schedule far behind schedule, the last (planned) ten minutes as well as the championship decision (!) could still have been shown. However, it seems that for legal reasons, F1 has priority and everything else has to be restricted, so Sky DE here probably had no choice. Nevertheless, it is still stupid, especially since Sky UK broadcast the race to the end. Nevertheless, a small compliment: the commentator Olivier Zwartjes has accompanied the difficult situation around the heavy accident well. Then there was again a lack of knowledge of the rules among the commentators Sascha Roos and Ralf Schumacher, so both did not know that you can change tires under a red flag. Although this situation occurred in Imola, Baku, and Silverstone this year, both only came to the conclusion that Verstappen could change tires when there were relevant radio messages about this topic to Hamilton. At Sky UK and RTL, both commentators immediately knew that Verstappen had this option. I am of the opinion that elementary rules should simply be known if you comment on an F1 race for a pay-TV provider. It is also not the first time that something that is now allegedly possible or prescribed according to rules has caused confusion, both have simply had constant uncertainties in the topic of rules. Generally, I don't like the artificial commenting style of Roos, but I have to admit that it is a matter of taste. But what really bothers me is the serious unprofessionalism, such as ordering coffee by the (equally clueless) reporter Peter Hardenacke or "UuuuuHD" by Ralf Schumacher. Especially the latter brings a lot of chaos into the commentary, which he clearly does not take seriously. Not least, advertising takes over completely at Sky, in the final stretch Sky is the only provider that goes into advertising, as you can listen to the German soundtrack without commentary directly after the race on F1TV. Neither ServusTV nor ORF do this. Also, these two providers make less advertising during the training sessions than Sky, and as free-TV providers. Although I have to praise Glock and Baumgartner for their work, this alone does not make up for the disadvantages. The rest of the Sky Sport F1 program is also very sparse and full of repeats. Overall, Sky is really the worst German-speaking provider that broadcasts F1. Ironically, RTL does a better job with the four races they are allowed to broadcast, except for the advertising. So the magnificent F1 season makes significantly less fun than it would be with a reasonable provider. I would be interested in your opinion.
gpt_response: { "Fluency": { "Score": "4", "Explanation": "The text is mostly fluent, with minor errors that do not impede understanding. There are a few grammatical errors and unnatural phrases which could have been expressed more fluently like 'Not least, advertising takes over completely at Sky', and 'broadcast the race to the end'. However, the overall meaning of the text is clear and easily understandable." } }

translation2: Rottinger brake discs are designed for the demands of the dynamic driver, ensuring reliability and safety when braking even under difficult conditions. Rottinger brake discs are manufactured by casting and then mechanically processed (bored and cut). All machined discs are produced in short series according to individual technical properties, which are specific to certain discs and patterns. Based on the individual technical drawing, a special production program is created that focuses on the outfitting of the disc according to the properties of the original mounting. The thus produced machined discs ensure high comfort and braking effectiveness. Additionally created openings increase the effectiveness of cooling the disc, where the cutouts improve the cleaning of the brake discs and brake pads. Aesthetic properties of our machined discs underline the attractive and striking appearance of each car, emphasizing the character of each vehicle.

translation2: Basketball Bundesliga: Disastrous Derby Defeat for MHP Riesen Ludwigsburg against Merlins Crailsheim  At least one youngster, Johannes Patrick, was left out. Again, nothing: For the second time in less than three months, the Riesen lost in Crailsheim - and how! Before the game, Ludwigsburg's coach John Patrick had looked back on the cup defeat in October at the Hakro Merlins Crailsheim and said: "We still have some anger in our stomachs." However, this anger did not subside after the game, but rather intensified due to the 61:72 (28:38) defeat in the Basketball Bundesliga. Whereas the result alone was disappointing, it was the way the team performed that was even more disappointing. For example, a statistic that expresses the entire dilemma: The three-point percentage was only 13 percent, with four shots (all by young Johannes Patrick) out of 31 attempts - more questions? John Patrick's answer: "We were not concentrated enough after our victory in Tenerife and did not implement what we had trained." In other words, moving the ball. His opponent, Sebastian Gleim, reacted quite differently: "It was an amazing game to win for the second time against Ludwigsburg," said the happy coach. "It felt like in front of 10,000 people." Meanwhile, only 750 spectators were allowed in the Hohenlohe Arena on Saturday, but they made up for it. Not least because of BBL top scorer T.J. Shorts, who scored 22 points and led his team to victory. "The best playmaker I have ever trained," praised Gleim. Meanwhile, in Patrick's team, the key performers such as Jordan Hulls (0 points) and Jonah Radebaugh (7) failed across the board. Only in the last quarter (22:15) did the Riesen prevent a total disaster and came within eight points of a comeback, after they had already trailed 39:59. In addition to Johannes Patrick, Justin Simon also scored 12 points. Luckily, there is not much time left for brooding. Already on Wednesday (7:00 p.m.), the Riesen will receive the Skyliners Frankfurt, before they also play in Ludwigsburg in front of a maximum of 750 spectators.

translation2: I generally believe that children should not be expected to take on a parental role for their younger siblings. However, I also think it's good for older siblings to help out with the younger ones to some extent. They can take turns watching them, bringing them a drink, etc. This helps them learn responsibility, contribute to the family, and feel involved. As long as they are still able to handle their own age-appropriate tasks, I don't see a problem with this. If your K1 is content to be alone for a short time and it's okay for him, that's fine. You can best assess whether this works for your children. It's not like he has to take care of K2 and stay up with him for hours on end. From a legal standpoint, it may be questionable. Perhaps that's why the psychologist's statement exists. If something were to happen like a fire, burglary, earthquake, alien invasion, etc., it would indeed be too much responsibility for K1 to take care of K2. Whether you're willing to take that risk is, of course, up to you ;)

translation2: Heavy "Helper" Question: Amberg knows the solution What is a "Helper"? With this dialect word, sent by an Amberg resident, there has been ensured hefty thinking in the BR television show "We in Bavaria". However, unlike many previous days, the term was not guessed by the callers in the series "Host mi?". No, it was not a "person who is nervous". And neither was it "someone who has to get everything done quickly". That, listeners heard from the TV moderator, was completely wrong. Whereupon the man from Amberg revealed the solution and thus probably also surprised many Upper Palatinate residents. "The Helper", the audience learned, "is a cloth used to wipe the stove". Dialect researcher Antony Rowley, who has been consulted by Bavarian Television as an expert for years, confirmed this. With the comment that this is a typical Upper Palatinate word, derived somehow from the more familiar dialect word "Houdern". With which a gap in education has been closed - perhaps also for many who have lived in the Amberg area for a long time.

translation2: Friedrich wins 60th World Cup victory - Nolte wins in two-man bob - Sport The brand of Norwegian biathlete Ole Einar Björndalen with 94 achievements is the goal of the bobsled pilot. "I've calculated it, I would have to drive nine and a half victories per season to achieve it until Cortina 2026," said the double Olympic champion from BSC Oberbärenburg, who scored two successes in two days at the races in Winterberg. First, he repelled the attack of Johannes Lochner by five hundredths of a second, as he moved from third to first place. Then he made some changes to the material setting and drove on Sunday with 0.30 seconds a larger lead. With his team Thorsten Margis (SV Halle), Candy Bauer (BSC Oberbärenburg), and Alexander Schüller (SV Halle), he defeated the Brit Brad Hall. Austrian Benjamin Maier finished third. "We took a bigger risk today and were rewarded," said Friedrich, who also drove his 22nd consecutive victory. The Stuttgart-based Johannes Lochner came in fourth this time after finishing second the day before. Christoph Hafer from BC Bad Feilnbach landed in eighth place after finishing fourth in the first race. "If I knew what he was doing differently, I would do the same," said Lochner. Nolte wins with home victory - Podium for Jamanka  Laura Nolte won her third season victory in the two-man bob on her home track. After only reaching fourth place in the monobob the day before, she raced to the World Cup victory with her pusher Deborah Levi. Two-man bob Olympic champion Mariama Jamanka from BRC Thüringen came in second with Germany's fastest sprinter, Alexandra Burghardt from Burghausen. She achieved both Olympic qualification and her first podium finish this winter. Wiesbaden's Kim Kalicki finished with Leonie Fiebig in third place. "It was super cool to get my first podium in the World Cup," said Burghardt, "I'm super happy that Mariama is with me. I'm super happy with the development. There is still a lot of potential at the start, but the start times today were okay," she said, emphasizing: "It's not just pushing, but there is also a lot of work around it." Jamanka was a bit frustrated with the not entirely flawless rides, but said: "It's moving in the right direction."
